title: 19th century posters typefaces
content:
I'm looking for authentic typefaces for the 19th century stacked poster look. I'm thinking condensed slabserifs etc. I've attached an image of the look the client is going for, but I don't think it's a particularly good example. I'd also be keen to hear of any modern takes on the style. If anyone has any suggestions it'd be much appreciated.  
thanks,  
HD

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105105830im_/http:/typophile.com/files/amy_martin_2_6545.jpg)
author: hd steve

comments.content:
[Giza](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105105830/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Giza) provides a very versatile Egyptian for this sort of thing.

[Champion Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105105830/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100002), [Knockout](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105105830/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100013), and [Bureau Grot](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105105830/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/BureauGrot) are good for covering the Industrial Sans styles.

The members of the [Proteus Project](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105105830/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100019) offer some additional stylistic options, but aren't as versatile in terms of widths.
